clinical_study.brief_title: Intensive Referral to Al-Anon: Benefits to Concerned Others and Their Drinkers
clinical_study.official_title: Intensive Referral to Al-Anon: Benefits to Concerned Others and Their Drinkers

lead_sponsor.agency: Palo Alto Veterans Institute for Research

clinical_study.source: Palo Alto Veterans Institute for Research

brief_summary.textblock: This study is examining the effectiveness of Al-Anon Intensive Referral (AIR) with Concerned Others (COs) of individuals in treatment for alcohol use disorders ("drinkers"). AIR's goal is to facilitate Al-Anon participation and positive outcomes among COs.

detailed_description.textblock: In a randomized controlled trial, this 4-year project is evaluating AIR's effectiveness for COs. COs and their drinkers are assessed at baseline and 3-month, 6-month, and 1-year follow-ups. Hypotheses are that, compared to usual care, AIR will increase Al-Anon participation and improve CO outcomes. We will examine hypotheses using generalized mixed-effects regression models (GLMM). This project is built on the foundation that it is essential to help COs because of their own suffering.

primary_outcome.time_frame: The outcome measure will be assessed up to 1 year follow-up.
primary_outcome.description: Items are rated on a 5-point scale (0=never, 4=very often). Mental Health is the mean of 10 items (e.g., How often have you experienced feeling hopeful); negative symptoms (e.g., anxious) are reverse scored.

intervention.description: AIR is intended to facilitate Al-Anon participation.
